planto.planToItems:
Plan to: 
-Bring your binder 
-Bring completed Advanced Joint Care and Replacement Center questionnaire 
-Bring your list of questions, if any

Plan to: 
-Bring your binder and medication list 
-Bring completed Anesthesia questionnaire 
-Bring your list of questions, if any 
-Bring your health insurance info 
-Bring a copy if Advanced Health Care Directive

Plan to: 
- Bring your binder 
- Bring your list of questions, if any 
- Confirm surgery details with surgeon

Plan to: 
- Shower with antiseptic sponges the night before and morning of surgery 
- Brush your teeth and rinse 
- Bring your binder and packed bag 
- Arrive at hospital 1 1/2 hours before surgery 
- Follow pre-admission testing instructions for eating, drinking, and taking medications before surgery

Plan to: 
- Check the range of motion and strength 
- Bring your list of questions, if any 
- Share any difficulties in increasing activity levels

activities.title: Ankle Pumps
activities.instructions: Bend ankles to move feet up and down, alternating feet. 10 times per hour.
activities.rationale:
•  Decreases risk of blood clots
•  Promotes circulation to lower leg and foot
•  Helps with ankle range of motion
•  Decreases swelling in knee, if done with other exercises

activities.title: Quad Sets
activities.instructions: Slowly tighten muscles on thigh of operated leg while counting out loud to 10. Relax. Repeat.
activities.rationale:
•  Promotes circulation in your thigh muscles
•  Reminds your body how to activate quad/thigh muscle
• Practices straightening surgical knee
•  Decreases swelling in the knee

activities.title: HeelSlides
activities.instructions: Bend knee and pull heel toward buttocks. Hold for 10 seconds. Relax. Repeat.
activities.rationale:
•  Increases knee’s range of motion
•  Promotes circulation
•  Builds strength in surgical knee and leg
•  Assists with getting out of bed

activities.title: Long Arc Quads
activities.instructions: Straighten operated leg and try to hold it for 10 seconds. Relax. Repeat.
activities.rationale:
•  Promotes circulation in your thigh muscles
•  Reminds your body how to activate your quad/thigh muscle
•  Practices straightening surgical knee
•  Decreases swelling in knee

activities.title: Knee Slides
activities.instructions: Slowly slide your foot back as far as you can and hold 10 seconds. Relax. Repeat.
activities.rationale: •  Activates hamstring muscles which are important for walking

activities.title: Short Arc Quads
activities.instructions: Place a rolled towel under your knee. Raise the lower part of your leg until your knee is straight. Hold for 10 seconds. Relax. Repeat.
activities.rationale:
•  Promotes circulation in your thigh muscles
•  Reminds your body how to activate your quad/thigh muscle
•  Practices straightening surgical knee
•  Decreases swelling in knee

activities.title: StraightLegRaises
activities.instructions: Bend non-operative leg. Keep other leg as straight as possible and tighten muscles on top of thigh. Slowly lift straight leg 6-8 inches from bed and hold for 10 seconds. Relax. Repeat.
activities.rationale:
• Promotes circulation in your thigh muscles
•  Reminds your body how to activate your quad/thigh muscle
•  Practices straightening surgical knee
•  Decreases swelling in knee

questions.mainText: On a scale from 1 to 10, how would you rate your mood today?
How severe is your knee stiffness after first wakening in the morning?
questions.subText: The following question concerns the amount of joint stiffness you have experienced during the last week in your knee. Stiffness is a sensation of restriction or slowness in the ease with which you move your knee joint.
What amount of knee pain have you experienced the last week during the following activities?

The following questions concern your physical function. By this we mean your ability to move around and to look after yourself. For each of the following activities please indicate the degree of difficulty you have experienced in the last week due to your knee.

checklist: Register for joint replacement class
Fill out Advanced Joint Care Questionnaire
Check with surgeon about current medications
Schedule pre-admission testing appointment
Fill out Anesthesia Questionnaire and medication list
Fill out Advanced Joint Care Questionnaire
Register for joint replacement class
Review American Joint Replacement Registry info
Obtain prescription for post-op PT appointments
Get a dental exam
Find helpers post surgery for housework/meals
Eat a healthy diet
Quit smoking
Start doing strengthening exercises (both legs), if instructed by surgeon
Prepare meals for post- surgery
Place food and utensils in easy-to-reach places
Make clear paths between rooms
Remove rugs
Find a stable chair with arm rests
Place a non-skid bath mat in your tub/shower
Place everyday items at arm level
Have extra pillows for positioning and ice packs for swelling
Pack your bag

subsections.title: What to pack for your hospital stay
What to expect in the hospital
What to expect right after surgery

faq.question: What type of artificial knee is right for me?
faq.answer: Your surgeon will choose the artificial knee components based on your age, weight and medical condition. Most orthopedic surgeons prefer a cemented tibial component, but that version isn’t right for every patient. The weight-bearing surfaces in total knee replacement are metal on polyethylene or ceramic on polyethylene.

faq.question: How long will my joint replacement last?
faq.answer: Your knee replacement is expected to last for 20 years or more. We are fortunate that modern implant materials have significantly reduced wear rates. These new materials have dramatically increased the life span of today’s total knee replacements.

faq.question: Why do knee replacements sometimes fail?
faq.answer: Infection is the primary reason. Also, over years, the surfaces of implant parts may wear down, and the components may loosen. Sometimes, scarring of the knee can occur, and limit motion in the knee.

faq.question: How long will the operation take?
faq.answer: The actual surgery usually lasts from one to two hours, plus another one to two hours for prep and recovery in the operating room. The length of the surgery depends on your health and medical needs, as well as your size. Larger patients with more knee problems require longer surgical time.

faq.question: How long will I be in the hospital?
faq.answer: The average hospital stay is two nights. Your discharge from the hospital depends on your ability to eat, control your pain and your progress with physical therapy.

faq.question: When can I drive, resume sexual activity, play golf?
faq.answer: Your surgeon will advise you regarding resuming your normal activities depending on your individual health and how quickly you recover from surgery. Most people can resume normal activities in four to eight weeks.

faq.question: Who should I contact if I have questions about surgery?
faq.answer: Contact your patient navigator at 650-696-5522 or your surgeon’s office.
